column7: Founded in the Queensland outback in 1920, Qantas has become Australia's largest domestic and international airline. Qantas has a range of subsidiary businesses supporting the Group's overall operations.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: The group entities included during the reporting period are Qantas, Jetstar, Qantas Loyalty, Qantas Freight, and Qantas Support Service.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: The sustainability report (sustainability report or Report) covers the period from 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023 (FY23) for Qantas Airways Limited and its wholly-owned entities (unless stated otherwise).
Qantas restatement information includes customer, community, safety, employee, and environment.
KPMG provides external assurance for the reporting period.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: The Qantas Group's primary business is the transportation of customers using two complementary airline brands Ã¢ÂÂ Qantas and Jetstar Ã¢ÂÂ operating regional, domestic and international services. It also involves a range of operational functions, both in-house and contracted, including pilot and cabin crew operations, aircraft engineering and maintenance, catering and cleaning services, freight processing and other active airline support services.

Qantas's global workforce consists of more than 27,0001 employees across 27 countries,2 of whom 95 per cent are directly employed by a Group entity, either by an individual contract or under enterprise agreements (EA) and by relevant national employment legislation.

The group operations also include a proportion of indirect workers who deliver services under contracts between the group and specialist providers, whereby we are one of many clients. These indirect workers have contractors, contingent workers, and outsourced labour hire resources that support our business in cabin crew, ground handling, baggage services, catering, cleaning, security services, information technology, and payroll services.
Qantas's governance structure includes the Safety, Health, Environment and Security Committee (CHESS), Audit Committee, Remuneration Committee, and Nominations Committee.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: The nomination committee oversees the meticulous process of selecting candidates for the highest governance body, ensuring a thorough and transparent evaluation to identify individuals best suited for these pivotal leadership roles.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Richard Goyder AO is the Independent, Non-Executive Director and Chairman.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Qantas Board of Directors is responsible for overseeing that Qantas has an appropriate corporate governance framework to enable the creation, protection, and enhancement of shareholder value. Accountable, ethical, and sustainable business practices are critical to this.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Qantas Group is committed to complying with all applicable laws and regulations and conducting business with the highest standards of ethics and integrity. We monitor global developments in governance, rules, and business practices and collaborate across our global footprint to ensure we continue to meet these standards.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The Qantas Board oversees the adequacy and efficacy of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) strategies and frameworks. Four Board Committees assist the Board in its work across key ESG issues for the business.

column13: The zero-tolerance approach extends to ethical conduct and compliance. Qantas Airways sets clear expectations for its employees regarding ethical behaviour, anti-corruption measures, and compliance with regulations. Rigorous training programs ensure that every staff member understands the gravity of these expectations. The airline actively promotes a culture of transparency, where employees are encouraged to report any wrongdoing without fear of reprisal.
column20: Zero-tolerance approach, crime and corruption, our Code

column13: Whistleblower Online provides a secure and confidential channel for individuals to raise concerns without fear of retaliation. This digital platform enhances accessibility, allowing whistleblowers to submit reports conveniently and promptly. The user-friendly interface ensures a straightforward process, encouraging individuals to come forward with valuable information and contributing to the airline's ongoing commitment to integrity.
column20: Whistleblower Hotline, investigate as necessary, employees and relatives

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: The Board Experience Matrix is designed to visually represent the skills and experiences present within the board, helping identify gaps and improvement areas. It typically includes an overview of each director's qualifications, professional background, and areas of expertise. This tool ensures that the board possesses a well-rounded skill set, aligning with the airline's strategic goals and industry demands.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: The Group Nomination Committee execute the evaluation process of the highest governance body.
The Group established a robust remuneration framework for Non-executive Directors.

column13: Under the Equity Incentive Awards program, eligible employees may receive company stock or stock options grants, giving them a tangible stake in Qantas' performance and value. It rewards individual and collective efforts and incentivises employees to contribute to the company's growth, profitability, and overall success.

column7: The total employee compensation reserve FY23 was AUSD 259 Million.
"As our 2023 Sustainability Report details, this past year we took significant steps to support our long-term goal to decarbonise as we accelerate investment."

column13: Climate Action 100+ is an investor-led initiative focused on companies it views as key to driving the transition to global net zero emissions. Qantas is one of 166 focus companies selected for engagement. Qantas engages with Climate Action 100+, and the climate change section of this Report aims to support Climate Active's annual benchmark.

Qantas Airways has recently unveiled a pioneering set of sustainability goals, marking a decisive step towards a more environmentally responsible future. With a primary focus on enhancing fuel efficiency and embracing greener technologies, the airline is poised to invest in sustainable aviation fuels, fleet modernisation, and eco-friendly operational practices.
column20: New sustainability goal, FY24 Performance, Planning and Review

column13: Qantas Airways has taken a significant leap toward environmental sustainability by incorporating the Airbus A220 into its fleet. Renowned for its exceptional fuel efficiency, the Airbus A220 sets a new standard for eco-friendly air travel.
column20: Airbus A220 aircraft, 25 per cent, less fuel

column13: Qantas Airways has embarked on a comprehensive Fleet Renewal Program, redefining the aviation landscape. This strategic initiative involves replacing aging aircraft with state-of-the-art, fuel-efficient models with cutting-edge technology.
column20: Fleet renewal program, fuel-efficient aircraft, 25 per cent by 2030

column13: The Group has developed prescriptive Investment Principles to guide carbon credit procurement for offsetting. These Principles provide integrity and quality criteria that credits must meet to ensure the carbon offsets procured are real, measurable, and verifiable.
column20: Investment Principles, carbon credit procurement, carbon offsetting

column13: The new Project Evaluation Framework will assess carbon credits procured against the Investment Principles. This tool will direct procurement by screening suppliers and evaluating projects.
column20: Project Evaluation Framework, overall Integrity, regulatory risk

column13: Qantas Airways has embraced the TNFD Beta Framework. This innovative framework, developed by the Task Force on Nature-related Financial Disclosures, represents a commitment to integrating nature-related risks and opportunities into financial decision-making. Qantas' adoption of the TNFD Beta Framework signifies a strategic effort to proactively assess and disclose its operations' impact on nature and contribute to biodiversity conservation.

Qantas Airways, a stalwart in the aviation industry, upholds its commitment to ethical business practices through a robust Code of Conduct. This guiding document serves as a cornerstone for the company's employees, outlining the principles, values, and standards that define acceptable behaviour.
column20: Code of Conduct, Suppliers, audits and onboarding
